sentence:
Mr. SCHIFF. Would the Senator yield for a question?

Mr. SCHIFF. I thank the Senator for yielding.

I just watched footage of our colleague--my California colleague-- Senator Alex Padilla, being forcibly removed from…

Mr. WYDEN. I thank my colleague very much.

I just want to make sure, from a parliamentary standpoint, would the  Senator from Oregon yield for my question?

Mr. WYDEN. Mr. President and colleagues, I want to start by  commending my partner from Oregon, who has now been on the floor for  close to 18 hours. What he is doing…

Ms. HIRONO. Yes. Would my colleague yield for a question?

Ms. HIRONO. First of all, I commend you for holding the floor to  raise issues of such concern to the American people.

I want to focus my question on the corruption…

Mr. SCHIFF. Yes. Would the Senator yield for a question?

Mr. SCHIFF. I thank the Senator for yielding and for your  extraordinary speech and all that you have elucidated today and for  your powerful advocacy on behalf of…

Mr. REED. Will the Senator yield for a question? I think he will.

Mr. REED. Thank you very much.

First, let me say that you are demonstrating incredible courage and  conscience today and last evening as you stand…

…impede access       to essential care for millions of Americans who rely on       Medicaid, including our Nation's most vulnerable populations.

Mr. BOOKER. I would yield specifically for a question, yes.

Mr. BOOKER. To my leader, Leader Schumer, I mean, that is the pain of  these stories from the families that I read of the fear that they have  to rely…

…the country  and create two-thirds of the jobs in America. Let's preserve this vital  program that keeps Americans healthy and safe.

Mrs. SHAHEEN. Will my colleague yield for a question?

Mrs. SHAHEEN. I think one of the things that people don't  understand--and I don't know if you agree with me--is that what is  going on here is that as these costs…

…understand they have to abandon their old talking points  because they don't apply anymore.

Cheap is clean, and clean is cheap.

Mr. SCHATZ. Yes. I would be pleased to yield for a question through  the Chair.

Mr. SCHATZ. Well, our grid is different, obviously, because we have a  series of islands, and they are kind of self-contained grids. But our  challenge…

Mr. WHITEHOUSE. Might the Senator be willing to retain the floor for  a moment to yield for a question?

Mr. WHITEHOUSE. In Rhode Island, we have a grid. ISO New England it  is called. It is through that grid that electrons get from powerplant  to the grid and from the…

Mr. WELCH. Will the Senator yield for a question?

Mr. WELCH. How are you managing to do this? You have been up all  night and your staff too. It is really, really quite extraordinary.

Mr. WELCH. Will the Senator…

Mr. MERKLEY. Mr. President, retaining the floor, I yield to the  question that is being posed by my colleague from Massachusetts.

Mr. MERKLEY. I yield for a question to be posed by my colleague from  Massachusetts.

Mr. MERKLEY. Thank you…

Mr. LUJAN. Will the Senator yield for a question?

Mr. LUJAN. First, I want to begin by thanking our friend, and I say  ``our friend'' because he is more than my friend, Senator Merkley. We  are friends from across…

…purposes and only hope that we can return to the traditional visa  sanctions method of dealing with particular events. In the meantime, I  wonder if the gentleman would yield for a question.

I wonder how this legislation with the new language would apply to  the case of Changpeng Zhao, the former CEO of the crypto firm Binance,  who was prosecuted for…

…because they won't bend the knee and politically persecute people  against whom there is no actionable claim?

Mr. KAINE. Mr. President, might the Senator from Oregon yield for  another question?

Mr. KAINE. Thank you. And I will tell a quick story. In fact, I am  going to hand you this picture now because my question is going to be  for you to describe…

Mr. SCHUMER. Would my colleague yield for a question?

Mr. SCHUMER. Thank you.

I first want to thank my colleague for taking the floor and showing  the American people how horrible this administration is treating  average…

…vote no on this amendment. We  can't afford the Washington business as usual that gave us $36 trillion  of debt.

Ms. ERNST. I yield.

Mr. VAN HOLLEN. Would the Senator yield for a question?

Ms. ERNST. No.
